title: Typhoid Vaccine,Live,Attenuated Oral: Uses, Side Effects, Interactions, Pictures, Warnings & Dosing - WebMD
description: Find patient medical information for typhoid vaccine,live,attenuated oral on WebMD including its uses, side effects and safety, interactions, pictures, warnings and user ratings.
cleaned_text: Uses This [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) is used to help prevent infection ( [typhoid fever](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/typhoid)) caused by a certain bacteria ( [Salmonella](https://www.webmd.com/food-recipes/food-poisoning/salmonella-faq) typhi). People can get this infection by eating contaminated food or drinking contaminated water. This [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide) is recommended for people older than 6 years who are traveling to areas where [typhoid](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/typhoid) fever is common (such as countries in Central and South America, Africa, Asia), who are exposed to someone with ongoing typhoid infection, or who work with the bacteria in a lab.Typhoid vaccine contains live bacteria that have been weakened. It works by causing the body to produce its own protection ( [antibodies](https://www.webmd.com/baby/antibody-testing)) against the bacteria that cause typhoid fever. How use Typhoid Vaccin,Live,Attenuated Capsule,Delayed Release (Enteric Coated) (Capsule,Delayed information available from your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional before taking the [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide). If you have any questions, ask your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/video/what-is-the-aca) professional. Before taking each dose, inspect the foil [blister](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/understanding-blisters-basics) pack to make sure it is completely sealed. Carefully open the [blister](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/ss/slideshow-blisters) pack and inspect the capsule to make sure it is not damaged. Consult your health care professional if the foil blister pack or capsule is damaged. Take this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) by [mouth](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/anatomy-of-the-mouth) without food as directed by your health care professional, usually every other day for 4 doses. Swallow the capsule whole with cold or barely warm liquid about 1 hour before a meal. Place the capsule in your [mouth](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/ss/slideshow-mouth-problems) and swallow with the liquid right away. Do not chew, crush, or hold the capsule in your [mouth](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/rm-quiz-mouth-myths). Follow the dosing schedule closely for the vaccine to be most effective. To help you remember, mark your calendar to keep track of when to take your next dose. You should complete your course of the vaccine at least 1 week before possible exposure to [typhoid fever](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/typhoid). You may need a booster vaccine if you still remain at risk for [typhoid](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/typhoid) fever after 5 years. Ask your health care professional for more details. This vaccine should not be taken at the same time as other [vaccines](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) taken by mouth (such as [cholera](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/cholera-faq) vaccine). Ask the health care professional for more details. Side Effects [Nausea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting) may occur. If this effect lasts or gets worse, tell [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional promptly. Remember that this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) has been prescribed because your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/video/what-is-the-aca) professional has judged that the benefit to you is greater than the risk of side effects. Many people using this medication do not have serious side effects. A very serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergic-reaction-causes) to this drug is rare. However, get medical help right away if you notice any symptoms of a serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/anaphylaxis-15/slideshow-allergy-triggers), including: [trouble breathing](https://www.webmd.com/lung/breathing-problems-causes-tests-treatments). This is not a complete list of possible side effects. If you notice other effects not listed above, contact health care professional. Contact the health care professional for medical advice about side effects. The following numbers do not provide medical advice, but in the US you may report side effects to the [Vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS) at 1-800-822-7967. In Canada, you may call the [Vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide) Safety Section at Public Health Agency of Canada at 1-866-844-0018. Precautions Before taking the [typhoid](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/typhoid) [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation), tell your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional if you are allergic to it; or if you have any other [allergies](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergy-relief-10/slideshow-allergy-myths-facts). This product may contain inactive ingredients, which can cause allergic reactions or other problems. Talk to your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/video/what-is-the-aca) professional for more details. Before taking this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide), tell your health care professional your medical history, especially of: current fever/illness, current [stomach problems](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting) [immune system disorders](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/autoimmune-diseases) (such as due to [HIV](https://www.webmd.com/hiv-aids/understanding-aids-hiv-basics) infection, certain cancers such as [leukemia](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/lymphoma/understanding-leukemia-basics)/ [lymphoma](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/lymphoma/lymphoma-cancer), [cancer](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/health-check-cancer-risk/default.htm) or [radiation](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/what-to-expect-from-radiation-therapy) treatment). This vaccine is not recommended for use during pregnancy. Discuss the risks and benefits with your health care professional. It is unknown if this vaccine passes into [breast](https://www.webmd.com/women/picture-of-the-breasts) milk. Consult your health care professional before breast-feeding. Interactions [Drug interactions](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/video/vd-0801-atsp-12) may change how your [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) work or increase your risk for serious side effects. This document does not contain all possible drug interactions. Keep a list of all the products you use (including prescription/nonprescription drugs and herbal products) and share it with your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional. Do not start, stop, or change the dosage of any medicines without your doctor's approval. Some products that may interact with this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) include: [antibiotics](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/rm-quiz-antibiotics-myths-facts) (such as sulfonamides like [sulfamethoxazole](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-6015/sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim+intravenous/details)), proguanil. Overdose If someone has overdosed and has serious symptoms such as passing out or [trouble breathing](https://www.webmd.com/lung/breathing-problems-causes-tests-treatments), call 911. Otherwise, call a poison control center right away. US residents can call their local poison control center at 1-800-222-1222. Canada residents can call a provincial poison control center. Do not share this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) with others. As with any [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide), this vaccine may not fully protect everyone who receives it. While traveling, you should still take precautions to avoid contact with contaminated food or water (such as by drinking only bottled or boiled water, eating only fully-cooked food). Ask your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional for more information. It is important to take each dose of this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) as scheduled. If you miss a dose, ask your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional right away for a new dosing schedule. Store in the refrigerator. Do not freeze. Protect from light and moisture. Keep all [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) away from children and pets. Do not flush medications down the toilet or pour them into a drain unless instructed to do so. Properly discard this product when it is expired or no longer needed. Consult your [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) or local waste disposal company.
